editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE RUMP: OR The Mirrour OF The late Times, A NEW COMEDY, Written by J. TATHAM, Gent.
Acted Many Times with Great Applause, At the Private House in Dorset-Court.
London, Printed by W. Godbid for R. Bloome. 1660.

list.head: Dramatis Personae.
list.item: BErtlam. Woodfleet. Competitors for the Protectorship.
Stoneware. A Scotch Laird, President of the Committee. of Safety.
Lockwhit. A Lawyer, of the same Committee.
Desborough. Huson. Cobbet. Duckinfield. Collonels, and of the same Committee.
Lady Bertlam. Wise to Lord Bertlam.
2. Clerks, and 2. Dorekeepers to the Committee.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: THe Author not distrusting of his Play,
Leaves Customes Road, and walks another way.
Expect not here Language Three stories high;
Star-tearing Strains fit not a Comedy.
Here's no Elaborate Scenes, for he confesses
He took no pains in't, Truth doth need no Dresses.
No Amorous Puling passions, here the Lord
And Lady rather differ then accord.
What can be in't, youl say, if none of these?
It is all one; he's sure the thing will please
The truly Loyal Party; But what then?
Why, truly he thinks them the better men.
But if in's Progress he does chance to hit
Hab nab on something that may sound like Wit,
Pray take no notice of't; for if you doe,
You'l spoyl the Poet, and the Players too;
They will grow proud upon't, and in the Street
In stead of Cringing, Nod to those they meet.
Yet now I think on't, 'twill not be amiss,
We'd rather have your Plaudit then your Hiss:
And promise faithfully we will endevour,
If you do favour this, to please you ever.

div.head: ACTVS Primus. SCAENA Prima.
div.stage: Enter three or four Souldiers severally.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: AH, Rogues, the business is done,

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: In a dish I Warrant you,

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.l: And thrown out oth' Windows:
The Town's Our own, Boys,

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: And all the Wealth in't.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: And Wenches to boot Boyes.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Boot me no Boots, 'tis Bootless, 'till we have 'um,

sp.speaker: 4. Souldier.
sp.p: Those are Commodities, I confess I sain would truck for.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Thou shalt have them by the Belly, Lad.

sp.speaker: 4. Souldier.
sp.p: Rare Recruits after a long March!

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Gramercy Bertlam.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Heroick Bertlam.

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: The Man of Men and Might.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: We were Oppos'd, and even at Push a Pike for't; though a wet Morning, 'twould have been dry Service had We gon to't.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Dry blows would ne're have done't, some must have swet blood for't; but 'tis prevented.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: The Nail of Providence was in't.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Or the parings rather; but no matter which, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Leymor was a Stubborn Lad, yet Bertlam fitted him, and in his kind too, his Rhetorick silenc'd the Mouth of his Pistol; it had sent a bad Report else, and a home one: But Bertlam, brave Bertlam, that carries Charms on the Tip of his Tongue, acted the part both of a Souldier and a Courtier, an Enemy, and a Friend, Exposing his Breast to danger, under the Canopy of Security; And all this for Us you knaves. He told 'um a fair Tale, but means to trust them no further then he can fling 'um:

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: That's some out of Commission,

sp.speaker: 4. Souldier.
sp.p: Or into Prison, or both.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: We may Lads in time grow up to something.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Ill Weeds grow apace, Brother, and thou art one of them, and in time mayst reach the Gallows.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Speak for your self, Brother, I need not your Oratory; well, Bertlam has Wit at Will, Woodfleet's an Asse to him.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: A meer Milk-sop.

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: A Whey-brain'd fellow.

sp.speaker: • . Souldier.
sp.p: And of Courage as cold as a Cucumber.

sp.speaker: 4. Souldier.
sp.p: A Fool in Folio.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Ambitions Puppet.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: A general in the Hangings, and no better.

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: What think you of Vane?

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: As of a Vain fellow.

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: And what of Haslerigge?

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: A Hangman for Haslerigge, I cry.

sp.speaker: 2 3 4 Souldier.
sp.p: One and all, One and all.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: 'Tis Bertlam for my Money Boys, he is Our General, Our Protector, Our King, Our Emperor, Our Caesar, Our Keasar, Our—Even what he pleaseth himself.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: If he pleaseth himself, he shall please me.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: He is Our rising Sun, and Wee'l adore him.

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: For the Speakers Glory's s • t

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: At nought Boy; how the Slave look'd when his Coach was stop'd?

sp.speaker: 4. Souldier.
sp.p: Like a Dog outlaw'd, the Pallat of his Breech fell down with fear.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: He told Us he was our Generall.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Of what? Bills, Bonds, and Obligations, or Green-sleeves and Pudding-pies.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: And we told him he was an Old doring fool, and bad him get him home, and take a Cawdle of Calves Eggs to Comfort his Learned Coxcomb, for he look'd but faintly on't.

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: And what said he?

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Said he! I prethee what could he say that. We would admit for a reasonable answer? We were better principl'd then so, Reason and our business were two things, what We did We did, that was Our Will, and the word of Command lodg'd in Our hilts. Alass poor Worm, Cobbet and Duckingfield shew'd him Cockpit Law, and O're-rul'd his Rolls, he understood not the Souldiers Dialect, the searching Language of the Sword puzl'd his Intellect, the Keenness whereof would have prov'd too sharp for his Wit, had he been Obstinate or persisted in the Interpretation; and therefore very mannerly he kist his hand and wheel'd about

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: To the place from whence he came,

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: And e're long to the place of Execution.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: No, hang him, he will have his Clergy.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Is he such an Infidel to love them?

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Yes, as We do: Barbers, that is, while they are Trimming Us; hee'd fain go Ala mode to Heaven.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: If his foot slip not, but if it do, his sinery is spoil'd, he will be so sootifi'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
2. Souldier.
sp.p: Why dost thou ask me that question? I am a Souldier, and so art thou, let's ne're trouble Our heads about it, a short life, and a merry life I cry, happy Man be his Dole.

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: And so say I, while We are here, We are here; when We are gone, We are gone, for better or for worse, for rich or for poor; amongst the good or the bad We shall finde room I warrant thee Lad, and Our General can expect no more.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: And now you have put Us in mind of Our General, I mean Bertlam▪ (not Woodfleet) (that Son of a Custard-maker, alwayes quaking) let us as bravely spend his this days benevolence, as he Nobly intended it.

sp.speaker: 3. Souldier.
sp.p: A good Resolution.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Rather a proposition, Brother; but where, how, and in what?

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Not in Rot-gut Beer, I will assure you, or Muddy Ale, Wine for my money.

sp.speaker: 1. Soul.
sp.p: Wine is the life of Action, 'tis Decreed and I obey.
sp.l: Blood requires blood, then from the Purple Grape
I'le suck my fill, spite of you, Jack a Nape:
There's Poetry for you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: A Pin for your Poetry, March upon't.

div.stage: They go out, and come in again at the other end of the Stage,

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.l: Bring us Wine there, come who sings?

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: Though the Morning was wet,
We are merrily met
In a house more dry then Our skin, Boys;
Wee'l drink down the day,
Ne're question Our Pay,
Let them heartily laugh out that win, Boys:

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Then drink a full Brimmer to him that intends
For the good of the Souldier to labour his ends.

sp.speaker: II.
sp.l: Let let him flatter and lie,
What is't to thee or I,
And Ape Noll in ev'ry Condition;
If we thrive upon't,
Let all the world want,
And the City kneel down and petition:

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: Then drink a full Brimmer to him that intends,
For the good of the Souldier to labour his ends.

sp.speaker: Souldiers.
sp.l: Hey Boys, come away.

div.stage: Enter Bertlam, and Walker his Secretary.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Trotter.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Has Lockwhite been here yet?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Not yet, my Lord, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: What wouldst thou have?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Nothing, my Lord, not I.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Thou hast not thy name for nothing, I see thy Tongue will keep pace with thy wit, and still be Trotting, I rethee leave off thy Impertinences, I have told thee enough on't.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Why my Lord, and it shall please you.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: I tell thee it does not please me, 'tis my fear thou'lt be my shame, I sent thee into France to learn some breeding, and thou rendrest me the poorest and the pittifull'st Accompt that ever Porter gave on a sleight Errant. Dost thou keep Company?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: What are they, of what sort?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Of the better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: 'Tis strange! thy knowledge being so bad:
Are they Men of Intelligence?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: I think so, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p:
You think so! sad, I professe 'tis very sad;
were it my Case as it is yours, and it behoves you, as you assume the Title of a Secretary;) I'de draw Mens Souls out by Inspeculation, and in the Inquest of their Faculties cull out such matter as would yield advantage to him I had relation to, and without this, thou neither dost deserve the place thou hast, nor art thou sit for Company.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: My Lord, I have done my Endevour.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: A weak one, let Thurloe be your President.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: When your Lordship is Translated to your Highness, and that you have Command of the Publick Pu • se, I shall be as ready to waste it, as he or the proudest of 'um, but I am but a fool to Explain my self.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: That time is drawing neer.

div.stage: He turns about in wrath with his dapper Dagger at his Breech.

sp.speaker: Secr.
sp.p: In the mean time I have not been idle, I have done something.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: What hast thou done that may deserve Recording.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Why, I have Endevoured to find how the Common Cry of the Town goes, as to this days business.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: That's something indeed, and how do the People rellish it?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Rellish it! why truly Sir it is thought—

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Thou wilt return to thy Vomit.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Why truely Sir it is thought, and if I may speak my thoughts freely, the Rump was but a stinking Rump, and sented so ill in the Nostrils of the People that they fear'd a sudden Plague attended the Concavity, and with much Joy blest the Rue and Wormword you brought to their Conservation.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Dost thou know what thou sayst?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: I could say more, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: To as little purpose—begon, I would be private—yet if Lockwhite come admit him.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Nay my Lord, I warrant here will be the whole fry presently.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Thou a Secretary, and talk so like a Fisherman; what Fry, you fool?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Woodfleet and the rest, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: My minde is not at rest while thou art here. Begon—
sp.l: I wonder Lockwhite comes not? hee's a Man
Has run all h • zzards, with as good success,
Except Old Noll, as any Man I know;
He was his Creature, and he now is mine,
And hitherto he has perform'd his part
In my Revenge upon that family,
So home, even to their doors, that my disgrace
Lies buried in their Infamy—How now—

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.l: My Lo • d, he's come.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.l: 'Tis well—Leave Us.
My Lord, how goes Causes?

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.l: They cannot go amiss, Sir,
Whil'st you are Advocate.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.l: The Sword thou meanest,
That must decide all Controversies.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: It will do much Sir, but Pollicy puts the best Edge to't.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.l: And that you have, come my Lord be free,
Where shall We set up Our Rest?
We have had Tossing times.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, Time hath been tost in a Blanquet; but I hope now We shall use time better then so.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.l: You may Trim him, Sir,
You have him by the foretop.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: If I thought so, I'de hold him fast.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: Now, or never, If you let slip your hold you are undone, aut Caesar aut Nullus.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: But the Remora to that is Woodfleet.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: Alass! you know him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: True, he's but of a softly Nature.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p:
A fine Commendation for a General, that should be rough as Warre it self, but he has a soft
place in his head too, and that's worse, how ever he's a fit Subject for your purpose, and therefore, Sir, use him as Cataline did Lentulus, drill him along with hope that all this tends to his onely advancement, fools are soon perswaded; And believe me (my Lord) that was the very Engine made him consent to th' blowing up of his Brother, a Gentleman in some sense better qualified.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: I, but a small Nutshel I am confident may with ease contain both their Courages, yet I know Woodfleet will sleer (he dare not grin) after Honour, and is as greedy on't, as a Cat is of a dish of Milk.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: 'Twill be ill bestow'd, Sir, if it light on him.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Wha • , a Dish of Milk?

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.l: You misinterpret me, Honour I me • nt Sir,
If you make him groom of your Close-stool,
'Twill draw more from your goodness then his Merit,
And keep his wife in Smocks too, during pleasure,
That will be (Sir) your Highness pleasure.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: It is not come to that yet.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: Oliver had it, his time is past, and your time's coming on, Princes have power o're th' persons of both S • xes.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Name him no more, I hate his memory.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p:
I confess I do not much care fo • t, yet I hate nothing brought, or brings me profit. I lov'd the Father of the Heroicks, while he had a pow'r to do me good, that failing, my reason did direct me to that Party then prevailing, the fagg end of the Parliament. What though I took the Oath of Allegiance as Oliver, your Lordship▪ and others did, (without the which I could not have sat there?) yet it Conducing not to Our Advantage, It was an ill Oath, better broke then kept, and so are all Oaths in the stricter sense, the Laws of Nature and of Nations do dispenle with matters of Divinity in such a case, for no
〈◊〉 willingly would be an Enemy to himselfe, the
〈◊〉 Beaf • s doe by instinct of Nature seek for self-reservation, vation, why not Man who is the Lord of Reason?
Oaths, what are they, but Bubbles, that break with their own Emptiness.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: You say very right, my Lord, I am of your Opinion.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: Yet the Pulpiteirs belch forth Fire and Brimstone against it: But my Lord, how could I have serv'd my Countrey, by setting the Dane and Sweed by the Ears, while the Thread for a Protectorian interest was spinning here? how could I have carried on, or rather promoted the Design for Iamaica, (though it went in Revilo's name?) how could I have lopt off those ill branches to the Common wealth, the Cavaliers and Essex his discontented Reformadoes? how could I have shew'd my self loyal to your Interest, by foolling Fleetwood in the disseating of Dick, by his dissolving the honest Parliament as they call it, and bringing in the Odious Rump? how could I in my Speech at the Councel of State, have raked up Revilo's ashes, by bespattering him and his family, and told Ireto • , how Providence had brought things about, and that the hand of the Lord was in't, when I meant nothing lesse? how could I (under favour) have advised you to this days Enterprize, if I should have startled, or scrupl'd at Oaths, preferred honesty or Divinity before temporal interest or humane reason? I desire (my Lord) in this case you will be my Judge.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, you are your own Judge in this Case, but in my Opinion you have done your self but Justice.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: And he that will not do Justice to himself, will never do it to another.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: You advise well.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: My Lord, take it from me, He that will live in this world, must be endowed with these three rare Qualities; Dissimulation, Equivocation, and Mental reservation.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: How now, the news with you.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: The Lord Woodfleet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: My Lord, he is come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Prethee—Thy wit and his may walk together, admit him—I knew I should be troubled with him.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: I doubt not but you have prepar'd your self for the Encounter.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: I am pretty well Antidoted 'gainst the Poyson, He's here—My Lord, your most submissive Servant.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: My Lord, I cannot Complement, but I am in heart your Creature, that is, at your disposal.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Seriously, I profess, I cannot reach your meaning, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.l: Our meaning's not amiss, Sir,
We know Sir, what we say.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Indeed, I profess I believe so Gentlemen, I hope things are now in the Lords handling, and will go on well, and become the doings of Christians.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: The Government has been all this while in the horrid hands of Infidels, Jews, Pagans and Turks—I must make him up a Medly.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Yea, Abhomination hath been in the hands of Iniquity.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: But, my Lord, those hands are now cut off, and all our Ambition is, that your Lordship would take the Government into the white hands of your goodness.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Who I, Gentlemen—Seriously—I profess—Indeed—And by yea and nay law—You shame me—So you doe! I can say no more, alass! I!

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: You—Why, my Lord, if you knew your self as well as I do, you would say more.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Truely, I think, I have been something in my time,

sp.speaker: Bertl.
sp.p: Something! You have been more then something.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: That's stark nought, (my Lord) but it shall pass.

div.stage: Within, where's my Lord Bertlam? where's my Lord Bertlam?

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: The Lord Stonware, the Lord Huson, Colonel Cobbet, Colonel Duckinfield, and others, desire your favourable and Courteous Admittance, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: By all means, let them Enter: but my Lord be sparing of your Speech, for these are Catching fellows, and will interpret strangely, Our aim is onely to advance your Interest.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: You know my Lord, I can keep my Tongue within my Teeth, sometimes.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: 'Tis a high point of Wisdom in you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Oddso they are here, I cry Mum—

div.stage: Enter Stonware, Desborough, Huson, Cobbet, Duckinfield.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: The less you speak, the better 'twill be, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: My Lord Stonware.

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: Many Benisons lite on you for this days wark my good Loord.

sp.speaker: Desborough.
sp.p: How do you do my Lord Woodfleet? how do you my Lord Bertlam, how do you my Lord Lockwhite? and how do you all? Hah.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: The better for your asking, Sir.

sp.speaker: Desborough.
sp.p: Say you so, then I'le ask again, and how? and how?

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: And what? and what?

sp.speaker: Cobbet.
sp.p: Your Language cannot be Translated, Brother,

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Let them take me by the meaning then.

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: By th' Members, hawd there my Loord, 'tis sere, and faw pley, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Duckinfield.
sp.p: My Lords, I have not been backward in this days business, nor any here I think.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: 'Tis confest (Sir) what would you infer farther upon't?

sp.speaker: Duckinfield.
sp.p: And therefore requisite We should know how things will go.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: As they may Sir, soft fire makes sweet Malt, you know that Colonel.

sp.speaker: Desborough.
sp.p: And that I know very well too, and you have said very well, as much as a Man can say, and no more.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: And that's enough.

sp.speaker: Duckingfield.
sp.p: But We are in a Chaos, a Confusion.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: A meer Chaos, a Confusion.

sp.speaker: Cobbet.
sp.p: And the People expect suddenly something from Us.

sp.speaker: Lockw.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, Rome was not built in a day.

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: Mickle Wisdome geod feath in that, Sirs, there's Mickle wisdome in that Ise sure yee.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: At three a Clock we'l meet at Wallingford-House, and discuss the business further, what say you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess I say so too, at three a Clock bee't Gentlemen, what say you?

sp.speaker: Duckingfield. Huson. Cobbet.
sp.p: Wee'l waite upon my Lords—Your Servants.

sp.speaker: Desbor.
sp.p: I protest I am glad of this withal my heart, for I have business in Smithfield where my Horse stands, now it comes in my mind, on my Conscience the Roguish Ostler has not given him Oates to day, aud the Knaves Hay is Musty too; well, my Man is such another Asse, farewell Gentlemen, I'le see you anon, if I come not soon enough, pray keep me a place in the Councel, or let my Vote stand for one, no matter how.

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: Au geod rason too my Loord, he's a braw Mō this, my Leords yee kenn him weele enough.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: And you too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Come my Lord Stonware, We presume you are a knowing Man, to what kind of Government stand you affected?

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: E'ne tol what ye plase Sir.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: What think you of a Single person? here's my Lord Woodfleet.

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: Marry an he's a braw Mon, Sir, bet are ye in geod earnest Sirs.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: What else, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: Bred a God Ise for him than.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: You see, my Lord, how heaven does raise you friends.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Seriously I profess my Lord you know, 'tis none of my seeking.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: Nor is like to be of your enjoyin—My Lord, a word with you, what if my Lord Bertlam were the Man?

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: Reight Sir—Ou'z in on word ya ha spoken aw, Sir, he's a Mon, inded Mon, gif Stonware ha any braines Sir.

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: You will live I see Sir—My Lord he's your friend now.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: No matter whose, he's a required Property, and must be used by some body—And why so Melancholly, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Woodfleed.
sp.p: I profess not I, I was thinking 'twas Dinner time.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Will your Lordship please to take part of our small Cheer?

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: No indeed my Lord I thank you, not I, my wife I profess stays for me, adue Gentlemen all—

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Your Servants my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Nor you my Lord Stonware?

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p:
Ne in geod feath, Sir, pardon me, Ise invited by a gay Mon Sirs, tol platters of bra Capons Sir, and aw
the foles in the Eyre, Sirs, I an marry Sirs, tol oue a my none Countrey men ta, geod feath noow.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: If you please to stay my Lord, y'are welcom.

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: Gods Benizon and mine lite on you, Sir, geod feath, y'are like a bra Mon, 'twould berst a Mons hert to part fro yee, Ise ce'n yar humble Servant my geod-Loord.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: You'l stay then.

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: I marry Sir, wi yar none sell tol deeth Sir, gif ye ta plase Sir.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I knew, a small hair would have drawn him to your Table, without this adoe.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: My Lord, lead Lockwhite the way.

sp.speaker: Stonware.
sp.p: Ater yee is geod manners Sir—

sp.speaker: Lockwhite.
sp.p: That's more then you know—My Lord I am your Servant.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Well I'le break off the Complement then.

div.head: ACT the II. SCENE the I.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bertlam, and Prissilla her Woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Priss, Priss.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Why, how now Priss? where hast thou left thy breeding, in thy other Pocket? Art thou not read in Times and Seasons?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I never was such a fool to put trust in Almanack-makers yet, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: What a Wench art thou? and why Madam, prethee? there's a word indeed, as Common as the Cries about the Town.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Your Ladyship hath us'd me to't.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
Prissilla.
sp.p: Insooth I cannot reach it yet, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Reach a fools head of thy own, sure thou art Mad, Wench.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: The Secretary indeed sayes I am a Mad Wench, but I thank my Stars I can make a fool of Twenty such as he is, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Agen, can flesh and blood endure this, I must new Mold thy Manners, Madam! there's a Gammers title, out upon't.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Seriously I know not by what other Names or Titles to distinguish you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
Prissilla.
sp.p: How should I Madam, I cannot Divine?

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Lord help thy head, why, he is gon to be made a made a Man Wench.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Was he not so before, if not, your Ladyship hath had but an ill time on't.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: The Prince of Men, you Baggage; thou art such a dull one.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I cannot help it, Madam, while I remain in Ignorance.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: I see I must open thy Eyes by way of Explanation; Then know that from henceforth I will be call'd her Highness.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Nay, now you tell me what you would be call'd, I shall Obey your Highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: It will do well, and 'twill be but your Duty, prethee tell me, how dost think I shall Behave my self in't?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Highly well, you cannot choose, you begin so soon, if it shall please your Highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: I think I am better shap'd for't then Iea • , or what do you call her Cromwell.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p:
Abundantly, for at her best She was but a bundle of
• —Madam—Lord, I am so forgetful, Highness I should have said.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: That's the Word, Con it, and be perfect in't, or I profess you and I shall part—
sp.stage: Priss repeats to her selfe, Highness, Highness, Highness, Highness. Enter Walker.
sp.l: What's the Newes with you?
Am I sent for to Wallingford-House?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: No, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: What a beetle-headed fellow's this.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Highness, you Changling; you must call her Highness.

div.stage: Prissilla pulls him by the skirt.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: No, and it shall please your Highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.l: It pleases me very well,
sp.stage: She struts it, and surveys her self.
sp.l: What's your business?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Gammer Cromwell would speak a word or two with your Highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Bid the poor Woman waite without, I'le do her what good I can for her Childrens sake.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Or rather for Husbands sake, if it shall please your Highness; good turns ought not to be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Thou say'st true, One good turn requires another, he was, I confess, a Man every Inch of him.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I, and though he was out with my Lord many times, he would be in with you, as the saying is, and please your Highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Well, I care not if I go to her.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Your Highness will decline much your State then.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Say'st thou so Priss • Walker admit her, I'le hear what the poor Creature can say for her self.

div.stage: Enter Walker, and Mistress Crommell the Elder.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: I thought I should have staid at the door 'till Midnight; Marry come up Mrs. Minks. Is there such a doe to speak with you? No marvail indeed.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Prethee woman, what would'st have?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Thy Husband by the Throat, had I him here, and I could finde in my heart in the mean time, to claw thy Eyes out, and make thee wear black patches for something, thou proud Imperious Slut thou.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: The Woman sure is lately come from Billingsgate: Priss, ask her how goes Oysters there.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: She's very quick of hearing, and't please your Highness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p:
Highness in the Divels Name, it is not come to that sure yet, is it? hah! Thy Husband may be hang'd first like a Crafty knave as he is; Did my Husband make him a Lord for this? to Ruine our Family? Or as the Word is indeed, Trapan'um? Curss on the time thy Husband was born, he fool'd my Son in Law to betray the Innocent Babe my poor Child Richard, that Our Fames are now brought to the Slaughter houses, and the very Names of the Cromwells will become far more Odiou •
then ever Needham could make the Heroicks; Wo worth the time.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Priss, I pitty the Creature, ne're trust me, alass it Weeps.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Thou ly'st Baggage; I scorn thy pitty, my Spirit is above it—Let me come at her—As old as I am, I can spoile that fine face, my dear, deceased Lord, did so much dote on, let me come at her, Hands off, I'le do't, thou Iezabell.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: She begins to rave, send her to Bedlam among her Consorts.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I promise you, you shall have, clean straw Mrs. Cromwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Out Rogue, Rascal, Vagabon, a fellow rais'd from the Horse heels, do'st thou upbraid me too? Ile be the death of thee, if thou com'st neer me. Oh Dick, Dick, had'st thou had but thy Fathers Spirit, thy Mother ne're had come unto this Shame.

div.stage: She falls back into a Chair.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Priss, a Cordial presently, Odds so She faints.

div.stage: Prissilla goes in and enters immediately.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: I run, and't please your Highness— I have it here.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Prethee give it her, I would not for a hundred pound She should die here, we should be put to th' Charge of burying her.

div.stage: Then Priss offers her the Cordial, She starts up and with her hand casts it on the ground.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretious Cordial-Water of my own making, Madam, I hope there's no offence in that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: I need it not, proud Woman, I Divine this Scorne will be Reveng'd on thee and thine.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.l: Farewel Nought,
Th'art better lost then sought.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: She has a Notable Spirit of her own.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: 'Twill get her nothing, She beats against the Wind.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: She's Wind fall'n, and't please your Higness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: 'Tis an ill Wind they say bloughs no body good, let her rave, and raile, my dearest second-self will fare the better for't.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: The fox fares best when he is curst.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Priss, Priss, a word or two, Sweet Priss.

div.stage: As they are going off, the Secretary pulls Priss by the Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Why how now Sawce? Plain Priss? Am not I her Highness Maid of Honour?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I know thou art a Maid of Honour, but the meaning of this, dear Priss?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: The meaning of what, thou Novice?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: That Madam is so suddenly turn'd to Highness, Is my Lord made Protector?

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: No, you Dunce; well, thou art the simpl'st Secretary! what must I finde thee brains and Understanding, know then and grow wise upon't, She will be Protectoress whether he be Protector or not: If he has any Honour it must come from her, for ought I see; she is before hand with him, and hath Install'd her self already, I'm sure my Voyce was Herald to't, thou piteous thing, question the Pride and pleasure of a Woman? I will have thee Scribe to know, the time will come I shall have Honour too, and be Courted by the better sort.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Have I been wanting in that Duty, Priss?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Wanting, why thou art alwayes wanting, never provided, still behind hand, never before hand to a Woman; this I profess, and to thy shame be it spoken: And therefore walk upon't, I have no more to say to thee.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: But I have something to say to thee, oh Ungrateful Priss!

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Ungrateful? and why Ungrateful, pray?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Hast thou forgot the small token I sent thee.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I was a small one indeed if it came from thee.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: The tweezers out of France

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Did Travail hither, but were as dull as he that sent them, they would not cut a feather. Is that your pretious Present? If thou hast no better, Walk alone for Priss, She's not for thy Company.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Nay, Dear Priss, shall We be Married.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: What are you so hot, Sir? there's a jest indeed, Marry, before your Prentiship is out.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: What dost thou mean Wench? prethee kiss me.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I'le see better Clothes on your back first.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Why, are not these good?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Enough, had not a fool the Wearing of 'um.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Thou may'st say any thing Priss, I may have better.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p:
When that time comes, and thy Wit is
more refin'd, I may say something to thee.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Oh my Dear Priss, in the mean time, let me but kiss thy hand.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: That you may, but hear me, be not proud on't, Nor take this as a punctual promise from me, I love my self better then so.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yet I may live in hope.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: If it were not for hope, the heart would break, they say: But odds so, I forget my Duty to her Highness.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: And so do I, thou hast Transported me.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Not to Iamaica yet.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Cromwell, and the Lady Woodfleet.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Good Lady Mother, be patient.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Good Lady Fool, hold your prating; Was ever Mother so unhappy, or Children so sensles • ly ungratious?

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: I beseech you think not so, things will make for the best.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Oh fond Girl, what hope canst thou create unto thy self can save Us now from sinking? We must perish, undoubtedly We must; though Ber • lam carry a smooth Tongue to thy Husband, it speaks not the Language of his heart, for that is rugged. It will deceive him as it did thy Brother, and the late Idolized Parliament, he set up, out of a Malice to thy fathers Memory, to make it Odious, because he pull'd the Babell down, yet now he has Usurp'd that Priviledge himself▪ let his pretence be what it will, it bears no other Weight but that of his Ambition, to which thy Husband is a Property.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Mother I profess I'm glad to see you here, ne're trust me law, how do you forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: The worse for thee, I wish I ne're had known the time Occasion'd thee to call me Mother.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Why forsooth Mother, if it please your Highness?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Oh Monstruous, not to be endur'd! I have been tame too long, the fool hath found a way t' upbraid my Misery, She had a husband dear Ireton, my best of Sons, had Wit, and by his Councel s • ilted up Our Honours, which thou pull'st down as fast by thy simplicity.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess, ne're trust me, I speak Ingeniously ne're stur now, I am no such Baby neither, as you take me to be, Mother.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: A meer Stalking horse to Bertlam's Pride; his Wife, that Minion, doth assume that title, I once, and my Son Richard's wife Enjoyed; She will be called her Highness with a horse pox, while I am call'd Old Ioan, old Bess, old Bedlam, old Witch, old Hagg, the Commonwealth's Night Mare; 'tis well, if any have the modesty to call me Gammer, or old Mrs. Cromwell, and leave out many other horrid Nick-Names, this Infamy and more thou hast brought on Us.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Good Mother, do not Weep.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Would I were dead; Nothing Torments me more, then that thy Father, who whilst he liv'd, was call'd the most Serene, the most Illustrious and most Puissant Prince; (whilst that the fawning Poets Panegyricks swell'd with Ambitious Epithetes) is now call'd th' fire-brand of Hell, Monster of Mankind, Regicide, Homicide, Murtherer of Piety, a Lump of flesh sok'd in a Sea of blood, Traytor to God and goodness, an Advancer of Fiends and Darkness; such as these and worse, could I but think on 'um, are daily cast into my Ears, by every idle fellow.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I pray take their Names, I profess Mother, I'le Order them, as I am here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p:
Thou Order 'um, alass! they value not so poor a thing as thou art, had Dick continued, he had
kept Our Fame up fair it the World, none durst have blemisht it. They tell me that the time is coming, I must make a Stall my Court, and learn to thrive by footing Stockings, and if that won't do it, must be (what I ne'r was) a Woman of Carriage, either for Tubs of Ale, as Suiting best with my Original Condition, or else for Oysters; I was made for Burthens, and am too Old, and Ugly to cry Oringes; If these Trades fail me, then I must turn Bawd, they think me tough enough t'endure that Tempest, and tell me there's a place call'd Sodom, will receive me and my Retinue; I know it not, but thus I am made a Publick scorn by all Men; And in that, thee nor thine, nor any other that claim relation to Us are exempted; And all this by the foolery.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess Mother I will be even with 'um, I know what I know, and there's an end, as I am here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: I would there were an end to Our disgraces, which I do prophesie is but beginning. What will become of that fair Monument thy careful father did Erect unto thy memory, before (least none should do't after) thy death, next to thy Husband Iretons; nay, even of his, thy Fathers too, and all that living bore a love to him and Us? The raging Malice of proud Bertlam is so irrisistible, 'twill destroy all.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess Mother, my Lord Bertlam is a very honest Gentleman, and he loves me well, I profess now to you; well, I know what I know, few words are best, I am, and must be the Man when all is done, as I am here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely, when all is done, shoul't be the Man will prove their Scorn and laughing-stock.

sp.speaker: Woodfl.
sp.p: I profess now Mother, in sober sadness, I scorn the words, so I do—You know what I told you, Sweet heart, as I am here.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Very well, and do believe't, though you forsooth are so doubtful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Doubtful, of what? of that I never heard.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: No more words, but Mum, I say, I charge you Sweet-heart.

div.stage: Enter a Messenger from the Committee of Safety.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: My Lord, the Councel waites your coming.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Why law ye now, as I am here, you thought I warrant, I should not be sent for neither; I profess forsooth Mother you are very hard of belief—Tell the Lords I'm coming.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: I shall, my Lord, most honoured Lady your most humble Servant. Your humble Servant Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: I have seen this fellows face before, methinks he does retain something oth' duty he paid me formerly.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Be put patient Mother, I'le warrant, things will go according to your wish.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I, if you'l have some patience, if not, I profess Mother I cannot tell how to help it, for I must to Coach, that's the truth on't. Sweet-heart, pray make much of my Mother.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Will you please to walk in, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: My heart was very heavy when I came hither, 'tis somewhat now at ease, by the disburthening of my Oppressing Griefs.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: I hope forsooth, you'l have no cause to Create more of them.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Hast thou Summoned those inferiour things?

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: What the Ladies of the last Edition?

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Those whose husbands have been Stygmatiz'd by Noll and Dick, with the Title of Baronets.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: I gave Order to Trotter to Trot about it, an't shall please your Highness.

sp.speaker: Trotter.
sp.p: The Ladies are coming forth.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Gentlewomen, for Ladies We cannot call you, your Obedience to our Commands is well rese • ed, if you persever in't you will Oblige Our favour: Priss proceed.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: By what Authority, and from whom do you derive your Titles of Madams, I pray.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: From Our Husbands.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: What are they? of what standing?

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.p: Of no long standing, We confess.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: That's a common complaint, and a general grievance.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: And shall be taken into consideration for a thing we know; Priss, prick that down in your Note book: Who made your Husbands Knights?

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: Oliver the first

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Of horried memory, put that in your Note book, Priss,

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: And Richard.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: Of Sottish memory, shall I put that down too, ' • is remarkable?

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: By all means, put it down in the Margin, as a hand directing to the rest.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: Of their foolish Families, 'tis done an't please your Highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: What Coares of Armes do your Husbands beat?

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: Who? Mine, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: I, thine, Woman.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: You a Lady, and shew so little manners: Forget her Highness!

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: I pass by their dirty breeding. Woman. We say, what Coat of Arms does thy Husband give?

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: He bears Argent upon a Bend Gules, three Cuekolds Heads Attyr'd Or.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Three Cuckolds Heads! Why one is sufficient in all conscience.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis a Paternal Coat belonging to the Family of the Wittals.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: It may be they were Founders of Cuckoldsaven.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: No more of Cuckolds, Priss, 'tis approbrious, and intrencheth much upon the Honor of our Sex: Put that down in your Note-book as a publick Grievance, and it concerns Us to look after, and the Committee of Safety to Remedy.

sp.speaker: 2 La.
sp.p: 'Tis a material and punctual point to a Woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: And what does thy Husband give, prithee?

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: He bears Three Gantlets Dexter Or.

sp.speaker: Priscilla.
sp.p: Or again: Your Highness may perceive they have had Golden times on't.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Dexter Or: Well, we know he has been an Ambo-dexter all his life time, and he shall now give another Coat; A Body without a Head in a Field Sable—And what's thine, prithee?

sp.speaker: 3 Lady.
sp.p: Ours is but Parte per pale.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Parte per pale: What's that?

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: A Motley Coat of two colours.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: 'Tis a wonder with what Impudence those Fellows Noll and Dick could Knightifie your Husbands! For 'tis a Rule in Heraldry, that none can make a Knight but he that is a Knight himself: 'Tis Zanca Panca's Case in Donquixott.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: If none can make a Knight but he that is a Knight, how shall our Husbands receive honor from your Husband, who is no Knight himself?

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Let me alone to Dub him.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: You have done that already, and 't please your Highness.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: If Dubbing our Husbands will carry it, we can do that our selves.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: But Ours is of greater Honor and Antiquity, and therefore ought to take place. Receive that as a Maxime from Us, dispute no further.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: We shall not.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Since, being Infranchis'd through our grace and favour you are become Members of Our Common-wealth, Declare your Grievances, and we'l hear 'em, whether publick or private.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: Begin with the private first, Sweet Mrs. Priss.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: This Lady complains her Husband prays too much, and it take him off his other business.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: There can be no Charity in that Man is remiss in his Benevolence. Receive that as another Maxime—Priss, You mind Us not.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: I'm pricking of it down▪ and't please your highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: But, it may be he prays when's Zeal's on fire (as Bells ring) backwards.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: And then he • ails against the Whore of Babylon, and then the people think he calls me Who • e.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: That's gross, and shews small breeding; We'l have it rectifi'd, it concerns Us.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: And my husband says I talk in my sleep, and call on Men to come to bed to me, and discover his infirmities.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Oh! have a care of that.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.p: Have a care of what? Were he capable of more care of me, I should have less care of my sel • .

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I commend the Ladies resolution.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: And, what sayst thou?

sp.speaker: 3 Lady.
sp.p: Why truly I cannot say much. My husband is a Man of reason, and is willing I should satisfie my self; he know the • ailings of Women, and imputes it to the frailty of our Sex.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: He's an honest Man, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Such a Husband for my money.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: As you are a Lover of Women, let the Act of the 24 of Iune against Fornication be repeal'd; Me thinks it frights as there were a Furnace in' • .

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: As there were Conveniencies in that Act, which ty'd up Mens tongues from babling, so there were destructive Inconveniencies in't, familiarity not so frequently used between Man and Woman. When know, Society is the life of Republicks—Martin the first, and Peters the second—Indeed, things were rather done in fear then freedome.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: In a Free State who is not Free?

sp.speaker: 2 La.
sp.p: I beseech you in the next place, that the Cavaliers may not be lookt upon as Monsters, for they are Men.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: And that it may be imputed no Crime to keep 'em company, for they are honest.

sp.speaker: 3 Lady.
sp.p: And men that will stand to their Tackling.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Well, we'l have these amended: What have you more to say?

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: Now, Mrs. Priss, to the Publick, I pray.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Whereas several abuses have lately crept in amongst Us.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: That's a small abuse; Love must creep till it can go.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: Her Highness hath the Feeling sense of it, and gropes out the meaning already, you see.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: We could not go to Hide-park, nor Spring-garden so much as with our own husbands.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Why, what had you to do to go with them? Could you find no better company?

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: Good men were scarce; and then to avoyd suspition.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: In my foolish opinion that rather bred it; what walkt with your own Husbands? How contrary to Conscience and high breeding is that?

sp.speaker: Lady Bertl.
sp.p: When things are settl'd, wee'l have an Act that no Lady or Gentelwoman shal be put to that Slavery, but shall have liberty to walk or—talk, with whom they please: Now may a multitude of mens blessings light on you. Priss proceed.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: Here's a Lady desires a pa • ten for Painting.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: 'Tis too great for a Subject, we intend it for our selves, and to that end, have employed several persons as our Agents in forraign parts, to find out the readiest and securest way for making it, that it may not eat into the Cheeks, beget Wrinkles, impare the Eyesight, or rot the Teeth.

sp.speaker: 3 Lady.
sp.p: I have found the woful experience of that.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: We have Intelligence of a Water that will in two hours time take the wither'd skin off the face, and a new one shall supply the place. That no Lady or Gentlewoman, though she have out-worn Sixty, shall appear above five and twenty years of Age.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: That makes your Highness look so smooth upon't.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: There's no Invention for sleeking, glazing, or annointing, but we have notice of; and for Powders and Perfumes, we may be sented a street off.

sp.speaker: Ladyes.
sp.p: Oh sweet Woman!

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Then for Attyring, and to find out the Mazes of Fashions, there's no Lady but must follow Us.

sp.speaker: Ladyes.
sp.p: You are at a great charge, sure.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: We are so, but 'tis Princely.—

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.p: We hope your Highness will remember the foregoing premisses.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Priss, be it your care to mind Us; We must to Wallingford House and have um confirm'd.
sp.l: And in the mean time, let our Musick play
To Celebrate the Glory of this Day.

div.head: ACT the III. SCENE the I.
div.stage: Enter one of the Dorekeepers, he trims up the Table, layes the Paper and Standishes in their places; then Enter 2 Clerks to the Committee.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: The Lords are coming.

sp.speaker: Dorekeeper.
sp.p: Are you sure on't?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: They are upon us already.

sp.speaker: Dorekeep.
sp.p: That they are not, Ile assure you, Gentlemen; However I will attend my charge. Keep back there, keep back there, I say, keep back there, make room for the Lords there. God bless your Honours.

div.stage: Enter Bertlam, Woodfleet, Lockwhit, and Stoneware.

Enter Duckingfield and Cobbet, they pass a Complement to the rest, Cobbet takes Stoneware by the hand, Duckinfield and they walk together whisp • ring, Bertlam Woodfleet and Lockwhit do the like, after a turn or two Bertlam speaks.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: It must be done (my Lord) we have nothing else to take him off.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: Scots, we know generally are greedy of gain, and since we have made him President, and sensible of our Secrets, 'tis requisite we do something to stop his Mouth.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Lest he—No matter, it must be done, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Say you so, I profess, seriously, If I thought good would ensue of it, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cobbett.
sp.p: My Lord beleive us, all We can serve you in you may Command.

sp.speaker: Duckingfield.
sp.p: And you shall find it so when occasion serves, and the Governments new molded.

sp.speaker: Stoneware
sp.p: Marry Sirs, a • ise sa mold itt, twas neere so molded, sen the Dam bound the head on't.

sp.speaker: Cobbet.
sp.p: I know there are some Ambitious spirits, would have it setled in a Single person, but we are quite against it.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: The few Deel splitt his pipe will be sort than, for Archibald.

sp.speaker: Ducking.
sp.p: But my Lord Bertlam is a stirring man, you see,

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bertlam, lett Bertlam gang tol Bedlam in the Deels nam, what ha I to da with him, Ise yeer humble Servant Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: How do you, how do you, and how dow do you my Lords and Gentlemen all, how do you?

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: And how do you, how do you?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Ah my geod Loords, ken yee me, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: We shall make up our number anon: Will you please to assume the Chair, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Marry, and Ise your humble Servant, my geod Loord Bertlam.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Come come, What Government must we have? what Government must we have?

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: I, I, I; What Governement? Let's know quickly: Come, you talk of Conservetat, Conservetat, 'tis a hard word, hang't; but there's tors in't, I'm sure of that.

sp.speaker: Duckinfield.
sp.p: Conservetor, my Lord! Conservator.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Conservators let it be then; When shall we have um, when shall we have um?

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: My Lord, We'l think on that hereafter.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Hereafter comes not yet then, it seems.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: But while the grass grows the Horse may starve.

sp.speaker: Cobbet.
sp.p: Howere, Gramercy Horse, though't has no tail to't.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Geod feath Sirs, and Ile tell you a blithe tale of a Scottish Puddin, will gar ye aw tell laugh, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: That Puddin will have no ent • o't, good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: I love to hear of a puddin, so it be a bag-puddin.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: So do I, if it be a good one.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred a goad, as geod a puddin as ere was cut up.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess my hair stands an end.

sp.speaker: Duckinfield
sp.p: No more Swea • ing, my Lord, 'tis not seasonable in this place.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Harke yee mee than, Sirs, mind yee me now or neere: There was a poor woman, Sirs, bog'd oth Karle the Speaker, Sirs, an heed gee her noought Whilke gard her to let a crack, Sirs; I marry quo the Woman quo now I see my Rump has a Speaker too. Haw lick yee my Tayle now, Sirs?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: My Lord, I know you have many of e'm, but pray let's mind our business.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Business, Why there's the thing; I think every man ought to mind his business: I should go and bespeak a pair of Mittins and Sheers for my Sheerer, a pair of Cards for my Thrasher, a Scythe for my Mower, hob-nayl Shooes for my Carter, a Skreen for my Lady Wife; and I know not what: My head is so full of business, I cannot stay, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Gentlemen, will you neglect the business of this Day; We meet to gratifie our Friends.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Nay, then do what you will, so I may rise time enough to see my Horse at night.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: Is that it? Clerk, read what we past the other Day; I mean the heads of 'em; what Papers and Petitions remain in your hands, referring to this Days business.

sp.speaker: Cobbet.
sp.p: Forbid we should be backward in rewarding such have done Service to the Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit
sp.p: There's Money enough, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Duckinfield.
sp.p: If we knew where to find it. However, Clerk, read▪ To Walter Walton Draper 6929 l. 6 s. 5 d. for Blacks for his Highness.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: For a Halter: Put it down for Oliver Cromwel's Burial. We'l have no record rise up in judgment against Us for such a Villain.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: But first let's consider whether that were good Service, or not.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: However, we'l give him a Paper for't: Let him get his money when he can: Paper is not so Dear, Gentlemen, and the Clerks pains will be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Geod Consideration my geod Loord; bred Sir, that Cromwell was the veryest Limmer Loone that ere cam intoll our Countrey, the faw Deel has tane him bith Lugs by this time for robbing so rich a Countrey; bred Sirs, I.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess my Lord Stoneware you are to blame, I promise you, you are; Why do you Swear so?

sp.speaker: Stonew.
sp.p: Geod feath I gi you thanks for your chastisement, Ise sit ye Sir, au professta, an se gif you ha mee.

sp.speaker: Cobb.
sp.p: That may bring you profit indeed. Clerk, proceed.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: To Walter Frost Treasurer of the Contingencies, 5000 l. To Mr. Edward Backwel 4600 l. To Mr. Hutchinson Treasurer of the N • vy, 200000l.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: O • nds, there's asum! marry it cam from a Canon sure. Clerk. To Mr. Backwell more 326 l. 16 s. 5 d. To Mr. Ice 400 l. To Mr. Loethur Secretary to his—

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: To Oliver Cromwell say, leave out Highness: You were order'd so before, where ere you find it.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Secretary to O. Cromwell, 2999 l. 5 s. 7 d. for Intelligence, and Trapanning the Kings liege people.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Marry Sirs, an ye gif so fast, yeel gi aw away fro poore Archibald Johnson.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: Oyl the Wheel (my Lord) your Engine will go the better: Move for him first.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Be it your business, Ile do as much for you.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: Content▪ Gentlemen, since we have set this Day apart from other business, purposely to gratifie our most concerned Friends, let us consider the Worth of the Lord Stoneware, a person of eminent fidelity and trust.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Geod feath, and I ha been a trusty Trojan, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Woodst.
sp.p: We know it very well Sir, I profess, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duckinfi.
sp.p: And 'tis but reason you should be rewarded.

sp.speaker: De • br.
sp.p: Ide scorn to let a Dog go unrewarded.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: And so would I, he fawns so prettily.

sp.speaker: Cobbet.
sp.p: My Lord, you are Witty, I hope we shall have no more on't. Huson. And performs his Graces to a Scottish Pipe so handsomely.

sp.speaker: Duckinfield.
sp.p: You may content your self with that (my Lord) he is our Friend.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Geod feath Sirs, an sa I am; wha denyes it?

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, we are not Foes; I am for you.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: And so am I, as live.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Geod feath weel sed▪ ye ken well enough Ise sure Ise a man can serve ye aw, Sirs: Sin ye are so kind Sirs, Scribe read my Paper to.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: You have a Petition then?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Geod feath I had been a very foole els.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Give us the substance of it.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: That your Honours would be pleas'd, in consideration of his faithful Service, and the constant charge he is at both at home and abroad, to grant him some certain considerable summe of Money for his present supply.

sp.speaker: Duckinfield.
sp.p: Order him Two thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Seriously, let it be Three thousand, Gentlem. You must understand he is much in debt.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: God; benizon lite on your saw, my geod Loord Bertlam.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Three thousand pound! Why, half such a sum will buy all Scotland.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred Sir, ye leoke bett blindly out than.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Gramercy, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cobbet.
sp.p: Well Brother, the time was, a mi • e of it would have bought all the Shooes in your Shop, I will not say your Stall for your Honour sake, though now you doe abound in Irish Lands.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Y'are my geod friend Sir, geod feath y'ave • ene hit him h • me. Clerk, gang a tyny bit farder.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: That your Honors would be pleased to Confer some Annual Pension upon him.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I think it but reason; he has been faithful, and I hold him a good Common-wealths Man, and the rather because Hazlerigge hath so bespatter'd him; since you have consented to his present supply, let him not suffer for want of a future one: What think you of 400 l. per ann. 'Tis but small; Say, are you willing to it Gentlen.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Are you pleas'd, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred, thar'es a question indeed; Onnz Sir, ye ha won my heart.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Then Gentlemen, since my Lord Lockwhit's Modesty is such he cannot speake for himselfe, give me leave to become an humble Suitor in his behalf—

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p:
That you will be pleased to make him Const •
ble of Windsor Castle, Warden of the Forrests, &c. Lieuten • nt of the Castles and Forrests, with the Rents, Perqu • sites, and profits thereof. Gentlemen, I need not instance his faithfulness to us and our Designments hitherto: No man here (I presume) but hath been, and is satisfied in himself of his reality; And therefore I am confident you cannot confer a place of so great honour or trust upon a person more deserving: But I submit to your Wisdom.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: 'Tis granted.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred my good Lord, what can ye ask that we sall not grant?

sp.speaker: Bertla • .
sp.p: I have heard some say, that Honour without Maintenance is like a blew Coat without a Badge.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Or a Pudding without Suet.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: You have made him Keeper of the great Seal; 'tis honor, I confess, but no sallary attends upon't; and bribes you know are not now so frequent as they were in Noll's time: Besides, my Lord is a person of that honor.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Well my Lord, let us be brief and tedious, let us humour one another; I love my Lord Lockwhit well.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: I move for a Sallary, Gentlemen; Scobel and other petty Clerks have had 500 l. a year apeice granted to them▪ I hope he merits more.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Let him have a thousand pound a year then, you shall not want my voyce, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: 'Tis a liberal one, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess soberly with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Does that please your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: Your faithful Servant, my Lord; but if I may be so bold to know from whence I shall receive it.

sp.speaker: Cobbet.
sp.p: Out of the Customes, the best place, I think.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Sure pay my Loord, bred a goad, Ise uphold you now, ga • g your wayes; on Scribe, let us mind meere good Warks, wee sall prosper then, aw my s • w, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Clerk, proceed where you left off.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Honyleybres 3000 l. upon accompt, Backwell for 9600 l. Worseley Aubrey for 2500 l.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred holt for tham, where the Deel sall they ha aw this siller, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: Ne're trouble your self for that, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: These things must be granted, we know the persons, they are our friends.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess, indeed Brotherly love ought to go along with us all; but when all is gone, when shall we have more?

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Pough, my Lord, the City's big with riches, and neer her time I hope to be Delivered.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Ile be the Midwife, or what you will call me, Ile under • ake to do my office as well as Dr. Chamberlyn can do his.

sp.speaker: Desbrough.
sp.p: Well said Brother, what's the matter there?

div.stage: The Lady Bertlam strives to enter, the Dorekeeper goes to the Lord Bertlam, and whispers him, he riseth, and goes to her.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Ile wait on you immediately, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Is the Lord Bertlam gone?

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess, I know not.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Why, how now Sweet-heart, What make you here?

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Nay, what make you here then?

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: This is not a place for Women.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: How so, Sir, pray, while thou art here I have as much right to the place as thou hast, if I am Iohn Bertlam's Lady, and for ought I know my advice may do aswell here as thine, for all you perk it so.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Good Sweet-heart, return to thy Coach.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Good Sweet-heart, tell me, am I her Highness or not her Highness, or what do you intend to make of me?

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Thou makest thy self seem to be a Mad Woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Do I so, Sir, Ile be madder yet; then Ile to the Board, and know what they intend to do with me.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Thou wilt not, sure.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: But I will, and hear what they will say to me; I will be put off no longer.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Be not so loud.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Ile be Louder Sir, and they shall hear me; If I am not Her Highness, they shall not sit there.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Thou shalt be as high as can be, if thou wilt be patient.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Patient, I, thou knowst too well I am a patient fool; pray, when will the time come I shall be styl'd Her Highness? for that I will be.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Ile tell thee that anon; prethee Sweet-heart take thy Coach.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: I, thou thinkst with thy fine Words to Work me to any thing, but if you Deser the time too long, you'l find the Contrary—Call my Man there—D'ye hear me? pray make haste home.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: My Lord, We thought you had been gone.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I have been better bred then so, to leave you in the heat and midst of business.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: Nay, I think the heat of our business is over for this Day. Clerk, See, have you any more Papers?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Not any.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Let us rise then, I think we have sate a pretty time by't.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: And my colon begins to cry out beans and bacon.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess my Lord, it is not I think fit to put you in mind, I hope I need not, I profess.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Oh, to move concerning a Single person.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: By all means, for his Lordship.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Seriously, my Lords, I hold it would have been unseasonable, but at the next Sitting it will fall in course my Lord, and then my Lord—

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: We are your Creatures.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Say you so, I profess let it be so then.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Come let us go, I'm mad to be gone; What should we stay here for?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Marry, an yee speke right, Sir. Scribe, See aw theise Orders be ready for my hond aneust Morne; meere especially my none and my geod Loods heere, that they may gang to the Pattent Scribe, here ye mee.

sp.speaker: Clerks.
sp.p: They shall, my Lord.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Come Sirrah, here be thriving Times, some men rise with their Breech upwards.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: And 'tis very probable may be lasht for't: How they Divide the Kingdomes Treasure.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: I commend them, they make use of their time, make Hay whilest the Sun shines. I wonder my Lord Desbrough mist that Proverb at the Table.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: Was ever such Language heard at a Council-Table before? They are all made up of Proverbs and Old-sayings, except his tamen semper, Bertlam and Lockwhit.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Oh! those are two precious Divels; but for a fawning and colloguing Divel, give me the Scotch Divel.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: No more of this, the Dore-keeper has Ears.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: I would his Ears were off, they are not worth the Sense of Hearing: But come, let's put up our trinckets; a pox on't, I did not think they would have sate so long.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: Thou hast some Baggage or other to go to, Ile be hang'd else.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Thou mayst be hang'd in time; however weel goe.

sp.speaker: Dore-keeper.
sp.p: Well, go your wayes, you are a precious Couple.

div.stage: [A noyse within, crying Tom, Will, Harry, Dick; Have you a mind to be Murdered in your beds.]
Enter a Corporal and Souldiers after him in a confused manner, as from their several Lodgings.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: What's the matter? Corporal.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: The City's up in Arms.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: And so am I, there's plunder enough, I am mad to be at it.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: The Committee sate all this night about it; 'tis said they are up every where.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: I warrant that Dog in a Doublet Has • erigg i • the Ring-leader.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: 'Tis likely, the news came but within this houre, and the danger that lu • ks in't hath call'd the Committee together, to morrow the Prentices intend to petition the Lord Maior for a Free Parliament.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: Let em', 'tis good fishing in troubled waters.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: Must the RUMP come in agen?

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: I know not, good Lads make haste, the Captain stays for us.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: Pox on't, let's ne'r stand buttoning our selves, Wee'l leave our Doublets behind us.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: No, by no means.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: And is't come to that, then hey for Lumbard-street, there's a Shop that I have markt out for mine already.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: You must not think to have it all your self, Brother.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: He that Wins gold, let him Wear gold, I cry.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Well, we shall have enough, 'tis a rich City, never came better news to the Souldiery.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: Wee'l Cancel the Prentices Indentures, and bind them to us in surer bonds.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: And they shall ne're be made free by my Consent till they have paid for their Learnings.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p:
Me thinks I see the Town on fire, and hear the Shrieks and Cryes of Women and Children already; the Rogues running to quench the fire, and we following the slaughter. Here lies one without an Arm, and he cannot hold up a Hand against us; another without a Leg, and
he shan't run for't; another without a Nose, hee'l ne're smell us out; another without a Head, and his plotting's spoyl'd: Here lies a rich Courmogeon burnt to Ashes, who rather then he would survive his Treasure, perisheth with his Chests, and leaves his better Angels to wait on Us, you Knaves.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: Oh brave Tom.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: I know you have all Mettle enough, but our Captain stays.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: Not a minute longer—hey for Lumbard-street, hey for Lumbard-street!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hey for Lumbard-street, hey for Lumbard-street!

div.head: ACT the IV. SCENE the I.
div.stage: Enter a company of Prentices with club;.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Come boyes come, as long as this Club lasts fear nothing, it shall beat out Husons tother Eye, I scorn to take him on the blind side, I'm more a man than so.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Thou a Man, a meer Pigmy!

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Children are poor Worms, I would have you to know that I am the Cities Champion.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Thou the Cities Champion!

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Yes, and will spend life and limbe for Magna Charta and a Free Parliament.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: So we will all, so we will all.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Why then you are my Boys, and true Sons to the City; Cry up a Free Parliament.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A Free Parliament, A Free Parliament!

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Boys, this was done like Men; but do you hear the News? My Intelligence is good.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: What is't Champion, What is't?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: There's a Proclamation come from the Committee of no Safety.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: For what? Champion.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: To hang us all up if we Depart not to our Homes: How like you that, Gallants; how like you that?

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: This hanging is such a thing, I do not like it; well, Ile go home.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Why now you show what a Man you are; I was a Pigmy as you said but erewhile; but now I say and will maintain it, Thou hast not so much spirit or spleen in thee as a Wasp.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Oh brave Champion!

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Will you like Cowards forsake your Petition and have no Answer to't? Rather let's dye One and All.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: One and All, One and All.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Why this is bravely said, now Ile tell you what you shall do; when the Sheriff begins to read the Proclamation, every man inlarge his Voyce, and cry No proclamation, No proclamation.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed; No proclaamation, No proclamation, No proclamation.

div.stage: Wavering their Clubs over their heads.
Enter Huson and his Mirmydons with their Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Was ever such a sort of Rogues seen in a City? Come follow me, Ile so order um.

sp.speaker: Souldiers.
sp.p: Oh brave Collonel!

div.stage: Enter Prentices at the other end of the Stage, crying, Whoop Cobler, Whoop Cobler, and he pursuing them.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Shoot, shoot; I charge you kill the Rogues, leave not one of them alive,

div.stage: [A Musket is let off within. Ex.
Enter Prentices again, crying Whoop Cobler.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Cain has kill'd his Brother, Coll. Cordwayner he has spun a fine Thread to day.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: It may bring him to his End.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: St. Hugh's Bones must go to th' wrack, and there let him take his Last, Whoop Cobler.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Whoop Cobler, Whoop Cobler.

div.stage: Enter Huson again persuing the Prentices; they continuing their cry, Whoop Cobler; Turnep Tops are thrown at him as from House tops; Boys run in.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: From whence come these? Search that House, and every House: I vow there's not a Street free from these Rogues.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Where hast thou been, Champion?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Where none but a Champion durst be.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Where's that? Where's that?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Stand here and admire; You are beholding to me, I have past the Pikes to meet you, and swet for't: I tell you I have been at Guildhall, and what I have done there, let Histories record. Ile not be my own Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
