sp.p: What didst thou do there?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Do you see this small Engine? 'Tis a good one, and has been trusty to his Master: I say no more.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Nay, good Champion; What, what?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: How Dull you are! With this (I say) heartily charg'd and ram'd, under my Apron closely hid, Latit anguis in herba, (There's Latin for you Rogues) I got into the Yard.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: What then, What then?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: By good fortune I espy'd a very fine fellow, some Officer no doubt, he did Ran Dan so.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: But prethee be plain and short.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: No it was home, the sting of my Serpent hath either kill'd him or lam'd him downright, I warrant he troubles us no more this Day. Heark, the A Drum is heard within. Rogues are Marching; let them go and be hang'd they shal not abide here, I have given them an earnest penny already, and if they come again, Ile double it. Well Boys, when they are past Weel go and Drink the Kings health: Say Boys.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Viva le roy, Viva le roy.

div.stage: Enter Lord Bertlam and Lord Lockwhit?

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: My Lord, you will still endear me.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: A Duty so oblig'd cannot be paid too often, my prayers go with you, my most honoured Lord.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: If I return, my Lord, Command my Heart; In the mean time, let not your friendship Cool.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: My body shall be Ice first.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: My Lord Stoneware, this is a high peice of Kindness indeed.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p:
Marry, Ise come toll kiss your none hand, Sir,
• re yee gang anenst the limmer loowne.

div.stage: Enter Walker and the Lady Bertlam.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Your Servant, my Lord—Walker, Are you ready?

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Direct the Lord Stoneware to the Blew Chamber; where Ile attend your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Your very humble Servant, my Loords.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: I know She's clogg'd with passion, and 'tis not fit a Scot should understand it.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: You have done wisely in that, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Have I stay'd long enough, may you be spoken with yet?

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Why not, Sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Am I a Wife, or no Wife.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: My only Joy and comfort—Why dost Weep? There's not a Tear but Wounds me. Prithee leave, I'm sure th'ast no occasion for't.

sp.speaker: La. Bertlam.
sp.p: Did Noll do so by his Wife Bess, that Puss? He had some care of her, and made her what her heart could wish; but I have nought but empty promises.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Will you believe me? This Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: He's a Lawyer, and may lie.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: He's my Friend.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: 'Twas a by-Complement, I confess; but I believe he knows more then you do. Pray Sir, say, Shall I be what I will be, as he says?

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: The power is now in his owne hands, and Doubtless my Lord's so wise he will not pa • t with't.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Say you so! Then prithee kiss me Iohn, ne're stir, I shall so love thee.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: But we forget the Lord Stoneware.

sp.speaker: Lockw.
sp.p: H'as got a Scottish Fog in's mouth by this time.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Hang him, 'tis such a Boorish stammering fellow, I cann't endure him.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: But he's a property, if I return Victorious, I must make use of; Therefore, prithee Sweet, be modederately sparing in thy language; let it not soar so high, lest it prevent my Towring thoughts of their fruition, and clip those Wings should hover thee to Greatness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Ile not tye my tongue up for no mans pleasure living: I think I am a Free Woman, no Bondslave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: But under favour, Madam, when you Weigh the Advancement—

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: I Weigh it not a rush, nor shall I Fee you for your Counsel, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: He's a good Man, Sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: La. Bertlam.
sp.p: Let him be neer so good, Ile have my will,

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: I prethee do.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: I trust I have not angred you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Again Madam! let his goodness be what it will, I'm sure, he hath but ill breeding.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: My Lord Stonware is going, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bertlam.
sp.p: Odds so, indeed, we have been too uncivil, come Sweet-heart, my Lord, will you please to walk in.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: How now Gentlemen? you are upon the merry March, I hear.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: I, a pox on't, We shall have little cause, I fear, to call it a merry one.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: Well, I thank my Stars, Our Regiment stays here at the well head, you Rogues, where there is plenty of all things.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: What says Pluck? The Worser knave, the better luck.

sp.speaker: 3 Souldier.
sp.p: But do you hear me, Sirrah? for all that, your Colonel may be hang'd for killing his Brother Cobler.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: I hear no harm, I'm not to answer for him: But prethee tell me, D'ye think there will be bloody Noses?

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: Those that have a mind to't, let 'em give, or take 'em, hang him that fights a stroke, for my par • .

sp.speaker: 3 Souldier.
sp.p: Or mine either; Our Company swear they'l all be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: The General is like to be well hop'd up with such Souldiers.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: Why, what would you have us to do? If the General cannot agree them, let 'em fight it out themselves and the Devil part 'em I cry.

sp.speaker: 3 Souldier.
sp.p: If they will fight, we'l make a ring for 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: They say that General Philagathus is a gallant Stout Man, an Excellent Souldier, and a Marvellours honest Man.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: Then we have the less reason to fight against him.

sp.speaker: 3 Souldier.
sp.p: Nor will we fight against him.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: But Brothers, let me advise you to have a Care what you say, lest you make your Words good, and be hang'd in earnest, there are Rogues abroad.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: I, too many, I thank you Brother for your Advice.

sp.speaker: 3 Souldier.
sp.p: A lack we talk away our time, let's go, let's go.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: Nay, sure Brother Souldiers, we will not part with dry Lips.

sp.speaker: 2 Souldier.
sp.p: What you intend to do, do quickly.

sp.speaker: 1 Souldier.
sp.p: Come away then.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Now Priss, what think you now?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Why, truly Secretary I think thou wilt be a brave Fellow when my Lord returns.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: You will let me kiss you now, I hope.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: No indeed Secretary, I will not make you so bold yet; If you return safe and sound, and in good plight, that is, my Lords brows circled with laurel, and people smell you out to be a Secretary of State, 'tis very probable you may have admittance to my Lip, and something else in a lawful way.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: These words have comforted my heart, I'm overjoy'd, trust me now: Odds so, my Lords upon taking Horse; ah! ah! Dear Priss.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Sigh not Man, thou shalt have it; come take Livery and Seisin, and adue.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Oh, So sweet as the Hony-combe!

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Have a care you do not surfeit with't.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I must begon, Dear Priss, once more.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Why law you now give you an Inch and you will take an Ell; I shall be troubled with you—Kisses.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: No truly Priss—

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Why, you are bold indeed.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Oh Heart! Oh Fates! Why should such Lovers part?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Well, go thy wayes for a Modest Asse, thou mightst have had something else, hadst thou press'd me to't; but the Fool will make a fine Husband; when he comes to taste the fruit, he'l so love the Tree! 'Tis a sweet thing for a Woman of Knowledge to meet with a Man of Ignorance, and better to keep him in't. My Secretary I see never read Arratine, if he had he would have been furnish'd with more Audacity. Lord, how Honor Creeps upon me! I shall be Ladifi'd there's no Doubt on't. How my Ears will be sill'd with Madams! And, Will your Ladyship be pleas'd? What will your Honor have to Breakfast? How do you, Madam? I am come to give you a Visit, Madam. Will you go to Hide-Park to day, Madam? How does your good Lord, Madam? Did you Sleep well to night, Madam? Is your Dog recover'd of his Fit, Madam? Your faithful Servant, Madam. Have you any Service to Command me, Madam? This her Highness despises. I am as proud as She; and me thinks it sounds very well. Madam! Why, 'tis a word of State.

sp.speaker: Scullion.
sp.p: Mrs. Priss, Mrs. Priss, You must come away to her Highness presently.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Why, how now, Sance?

sp.speaker: Scullion.
sp.p: Sauce! Why, what are you, pray? Will you come away? Ile tell her.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: Ile have you boxt anon, Sirrah, for this.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Champion, how now Champion? What news, Champion?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Nay, what news do you say, then?

sp.speaker: 3 Prentice.
sp.p: Bertlam is gone.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: The Devil and Iohn a Cumber go with him. Well, I hope General Philagathus will so pay his Jacquet!

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: He will be forc'd to turn it.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: That he hath done often enough already.

sp.speaker: 3 Prentice.
sp.p: The Rogues were well mounted.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: May the Horse founder, and the Foot die in Ditches! My prayers go along 'em.

sp.speaker: 2. 3. Prentice.
sp.p: Oh brave Champion!

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, If you have any Chink go along with me; Weel drink Philagathus Health. How they look at one another!

sp.speaker: 2. 3. Prentice.
sp.p: Faith Champion—

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Speak no more, your Countenance betray your meanings, I perceive your Masters are not so tender-hearted as mine; He's honest, lives in hope, allows me the merry Sice a day to spend till better Times come.

sp.speaker: 2. 3, Prentice.
sp.p: Thou art happy, Champion.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: You shall participate of that happiness! 'Twere pity such proper Fellows as we are should part without Drinking a Health to Noble Philagathus his Successe.

sp.speaker: 2. Prentice.
sp.p: Well Champion, weel make you amends.

sp.speaker: 1. Prentice.
sp.p: Let the mends make it self; Come away, begon.

div.stage: Enter Woodfleet, Mrs. Cromwell, and Lady Woodfleet.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: How say you so forsooth Mother? as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwel,
sp.p: I say thy folly will undo us all.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess Mother, as I'm here you alwayes harp upon one string: Ne're stir, As I'm here, and like the Cuckoo, have but one Note, Ne're stir now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: What dost make of me, a Hooting-stock?

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: No, I profess not I, I know my Duty, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Thou Wouldst fain seem a Souldier, and a Courtier, but thou art neither.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Good Mother be not so bitter, he's an honest Man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Hang honesty, 'tis meer foolery; thy Father had more Wit then to be thought one of that needy Crue; could ever Man have given the power out of his own hand, as he hath done, and to his Enemy, a fellow as fierce as Aqua fortis, and will eat into the very marrow of our families.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess Mother, you may be mistaken for all this, he is in some sense, but my Servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: And he'l become thy Master to thy shame, why didst not go thy self?

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Why? I profess, Whether you believe it or not, Mother, I am the greatest Man in the Nation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Until a greater come; How stupid art thou? Girle, prithee instruct him.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: 'Twould ill become me, sure to teach my Lord, I neer was guilty of that crime yet, he knows his own Business best.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess, Mother, you are such a strange Woman, I know not what to say to you; had not General Philagathus (like a fool) made this disturbance, I know, what I had been this time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Thou hadst been neither better nor worse then what thou art, the Common Tavern, and Town Table-Talk.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Why? I profess, Mother, you are not so well spoken of, neither, for all you look so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: That's long of such an Ideot as thou art.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Nay Mother, indeed you do not well: He's my Husband, I ought not to suffer this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Good Lord! It seems he plays better at Tratrip with thee then thy Husband Ireton did: Thou couldst find Tongue enough for him: Or, there's foul lyars if this March-pane fellow did not Melt in your Mouth in his life time.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: I thank you, Mother.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: What's that, what's that she says Sweetheart?

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Nothing, my Lord, worthy your notice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Had not a sool rid thee, thou hadst known thy Duty better. So much for that, farewel.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Nay, good Mother.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Let her go, Sweetheart; the house wil be the quieter, I profess.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: She is my mother, my lord.

sp.speaker: Woodfl.
sp.p: And I'm your husband my lady, as I'm here I think so: I profess I know not any body cares for her company.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: She does not come to trouble you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Yes, She does, I profess, and very much: I was just thinking of State-Affairs, and She has put all out of my head: The Committee have no reason to thank her, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Why, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Why, the Citizens are mad for a Free Parliament, the Counties are all up; and is it not time to look about us, I profess?

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, you say right.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: If a Free Parliament sit once, what will become of Us, I profess we must secure our selves as well as we can: the Rump (as the Wicked call it) must and shall come in agen, I profess.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: What will become of your Friend the Lord Bertlam then?

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess, I care not; your Mother takes me for a fool, but let me alone to deal my Cards, the Speaker and I are reconcil'd: But Sweet-heart, I profess I must be gon, I say no more, Bertlam, Stoneware, and Lockwhit are Knaves, down-right Knaves, I profess they have fool'd me all this while, it will now turn to 'em, I profess, let 'em suffer.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: I understood, my Lord, they were your Friends.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: But I have found 'em out; say no more, will you go in, Sweet heart? I profess I must be gon.

sp.speaker: Lady Woodfleet.
sp.p: I obey you, my Lord.

div.stage: Enter Lady Bertlam, and Priscilla her Waiting Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: I Wonder Priss, that none of the Modern Poets have been here with their Encomiums since thy Lord Went!

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: It may be Helicon is Dry'd up, or their Brains are turn'd Addle.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Well, I'm resolved to make Him that brings me the first Copy Poet Laureat, provided he brings Victory in't: I will Dispose of my Places my self, and be Lord Steward my self, or it shall cost me a fall. Lockwhit for all his art shall never Carry it.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: How, Her Highness become Lord Steward!

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: No matter for that; Profit and Service will come by't: Ile have the ordering of all Places both above and below Stairs, and so give out to the people.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: And good reason too, bir Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: A Counsellor, a foolish fellow, at every end he calls me Madam.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Truly, there was one call'd me Madam too tother day. Lord, we Women are so frail! I thought my self to be a Madam in good Earnest.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: I Priss, thou mightst, and be proud on't; but I, I think am somewhat above that.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: A Story, so please your Highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: I will have Eight Gentlemen Ushers, that Puss B • ss had Foure; Two shall bear up my Trai • .

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p:
Rather Foure, and it shall please your Highness; that Petty-fogger Loethur's Wise had one, and as I'm a Christian, another foolish fellow went bare before her, no Countess could have been better Man'd—
Well, it will come to my turn shortly, but that the Wicked Rump is sat; there lies my fear, Oh Woodfleet! Woodfleet! thou art stark nought.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: What sayst thou, Priss?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I was thinking, and it please your Highness, what a Canary-bird Woodfleet was, to settle the Rump, the abominable Rump, and pretended so much love to my Lord and Master.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: His love is not Worth the enquiring after, Wench; as for the Rump, I smell 'tis stale already, and must be pepper'd when thy Lord returns; dost think Wench it shall have a sitting place then, no I warrant thee, he that jerkt it when he came out of the West, will do the like, when he comes out of the North.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I, and it shall please your Highness, if he return with Victory.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Ne're fear it Wench, I have sent for Lilly, and Wonder he stays so long, 'tis such a Dreaming fellow.

div.stage: Enter a Servant and Master Lilly.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Here's Master Lilly, an't please your Highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: How now Lilly, hast thou don what I Commanded thee?

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: I have Examined the Zodiack, Searcht the 12 Houses, and by my powerful Art, put the whole regiment of gods and goddesses out of order, Saturn and Iupiter are by the Ears, and Venus will he rampant assisted by Mars the god of Battailes.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: This makes for your Highness, I love Mischief with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: How stands my Husbands fortune?

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: In the Alnathay of Aries, or as some others have it Salhay, being the head of Aries.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Aries, what is that Aries?

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: A Monster, I Warrant it.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: 'Tis a signe, and signifies a Ram.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: You Rascal, Do you put the Horns upon my Princely Husband.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: It may be a new peice of Heraldry.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: He's subtle, politick, and crafty.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Thou hitst pretty well there.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: Then in the Allothanie, or (as some have it) Alhurto, being the Tail of Aries, I find him eloquent, prodigal in necessity proud, inconstant, and deceitful.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Dost thou abuse me, Rascal.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: No such matter.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Alass! he means innocently, for these are virtues given to most of the Male-kind.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: He's there denoted to be fortunate in Warfare.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Go on, Fellow.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: In Adoldaya, being the Head of Taurus.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Taurus, What's that?

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: A Bull.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Darst thou Horn him again.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: 'Tis a Signe.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: A very ill Signe, the Signe of the Bull: But he does not mean, and it shall please your Highness, the Town-Bull of Ely.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: Has your Lord are a Mark or Mold upon his Members? If he has, he vanquishes his Enemies.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: He has that Priss, I'm sure on't.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: You are best acquainted with his Secrets.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: For Mars being with the Moon in the Sextile Aspect, incourages men of War, and in the Trine promises Success.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Ile love that Trine while I live for't.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: I wonder where the Fellow got all these hard Words.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: Lose not an Inch of your State, lest you diminish the lustre of that Planet predominates.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Why Sirrah, you grow sa • cy. Priss, Let the Foot-boy pay the Fellow for his pains.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: I hope she does not mean to pay me with Kicks: Is she angry?

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: No no, you have only put her in mind of her Majesty, she loves you ne're the worse for't; You must flatter her.

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: I have been bred to't. I take my leave of your Highness.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: But take thy reward with thee: Thou art sure of what thou sayst?

sp.speaker: Lilly.
sp.p: As sure as if I had the Planets in my hand; a man can say no more.

sp.speaker: La. Bert.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways, and if thy judgment • alter, To second thy gold Chain expect a Halter.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: What dost thou think now?

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: How can I think amiss? He's a notable Man: Ile get him into the Larder one time or other, and Ile make him show me all.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Show thee all, Wench! Out upon't.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: What, the Lilly and the Rose: I promise you, for ought I see, the Lilly is the best flower in your garden.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Here's a Letter from my Lord to your Highnesse.

sp.speaker: Priscilla.
sp.p: Hast ne're a one for me from the Secretary?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes, Mrs. Priss.

sp.speaker: Priscilla.
sp.p: So, this Fellow is Saucy, I must take him down a button-hole lower. Good news, no doubt on't; and then we shall have such Bonefiring. Ile read my Switter-com Swatter-com's Letter anon. But, her Highness begins to look pale upon't; I do not like this changing Countenance.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Thy Lord is Murder'd.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Then my honor goes to the Dunghill: A pox of Lilly and his legion of Devils.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Murdered in his • ame, his honour, the Souldiery have forsaken him.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: If that be all, 〈◊〉 matter Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Even call me what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I should have call'd you Highness, I confess, but I hope you are not offended; Lilly is a meer rogue, Ile never endure a Lilly hereafter, 'tis a flattering flower, and stinks abominably.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: He Writes me Word, hee'l be in Town this Night, he's sent for by the Rump.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Oh nasty Rump! But an't shall please your Highness, shall I seek out for eight proper Striplings to to man your Highness and four Spring-cits to trick up your Train, a French Taylor that has a yard thus long, a Cook whose Nose will not offend your Sawce by dropping in't, a Gentleman Sewer that can dance before your Dishes, an able Carver to cut up your Custards, a Taster that hath a sweet Breath and no rotten Teeth, a Baker whose hands is not mangy; who shall be Lord Chamberlain, Groom of the Stool, your Maids of honour, your Starcher, your Tyrer, Yeoman of your Cellar, Yeoman of your Pan • rey, Yeoman of your Pastrey, Clerk of your Kitchin, Clerk of the Roles? Lord, I'm even out of Breath with reckoning up your Servitors!

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: How now Audaciousness!

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: Why, seriously I dreamt last night, an't please your Highnesse, that we have been but Princes in disguise all this while, and that our Vizors are now falling off; and who would think that Dreams should come to light so?

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Now could I tear my flesh, all my hopes are lost.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: No, you say there's one a coming.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: How? this Woodfleets Wi • e will ore-top me.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Pull her eyes ont, and then let a Dog lead her.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Well, Ile do something.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Ile see your second so good, and 't please your Highness.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Hy Boyes, the Noble General Philagathus lay at Barnet last night.

sp.speaker: 3 Prentice.
sp.p: Say'st thou so, Champion.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: And the pityful, dityful Lambert, one of Donquixott's Lords, is in the Tower. H'as been a Whipste • all his Life time, and now is become a staid Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Well said, Champion.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: No more of that if you love me, Noble Philagathus must be the Cities Champion, Ile resign my Office, and yet be Loyal still.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Who will not? who will not?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Then you are my Boyes again; do you not observe how the Phanaticks are trotting out of town, some of the Rogues begin to mutiny?

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Hang 'em up then, I cry.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: So say I, by thousands; noble Phylagathus enters with love, and they go out with curses, or like the Snuffe of a Candle, stinckingly.

sp.speaker: 3 Prentice.
sp.p: I'm sure they have eaten our Masters up.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Even to their Bowels, that Trading is become a meer Skelliton.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Now I hope we shall see better days.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Ne'r fear it Lads. Philagatbus is right, and sound to the very Core.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: What will become of our Exchange. Merchant.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: What? he that turn'd part of the House of God into a Den of Theeves.

sp.speaker: 3 Prentice.
sp.p: The very same, the very same.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p:
Let him hang himself, and when he is cold meat, the Divel carbanadoe him for a Break-fast: But
heark they are marching out, and [Drums heard within.] Philagathus his honest Soldiers are coming in. Oh let's see um! let's see um.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: By all means let's see um.

div.head: ACT the V. SCENE the I.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Cromwell and the Lady Bertlam; they meet at several Doors.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Bless my Eye-sight! what? her Highnesse without her Train: Where is that pretious Bird thy Husband, Cag'd? His Wings are Clipt from flying: Faith now, this comes of Threachery: Had he been true to my Son Dick, he might have still continued honorable, and thou a Lady; and now I know not what to call thee.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Thy rudeness cannot move me, I impute it to thy Want of Breeding.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: My Want of Breeding, Mrs. Mincks.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: We Cannot expect from the Dunghill odorous savours: Were our affections greater than they are, they merit not half the Contempt and Scorn persues thy wretched Family, and the Memory of thy abhorred Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: How durst thou name him but with reverence: He that out-did all Histories of Kings or Keasors: was his own Herald, and could give Titles of Honor to the meanest Peasants; made Brewers, Dray-men, Coblers, Tinkers, or any body Lords: Such was his power no Prince ere did the like: Amongst the rest, that precious piece thy Husband was one of his making.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Would we had never known these painted Titles that are so easily washt off: Enter Woodfleet. But yonder comes the cause of all our miseries.

sp.speaker: Wood •• eet.
sp.p: Ne're go, yonder's my Mother; I profess, as I'm here, Ide rather meet, ne're stir, a Beggar in my Dish, so I had, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: And, art thou there? Nay, ne're hide thy face for't, though thou mayst be asham'd of all thy Actions.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: Why I, forsooth Mother? I profess, ne're go, not I Mother, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: C • ll 〈◊〉 not Mother: Thou hast ruin'd my Children, and thy self too, like a Fool as thou art.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: And me and my Husband, like a Knave as thou art.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Would ever Coxcombe have committed such folly!

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Or ever Changling done the like! Iack Adams is a Man to thee.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I pro • ess indeed law, you are strange folks, I profess, ne're go law: Cannot a man, as I'm here pass the Street, I p • ofess law?

div.stage: [Walks about the Stage, they following him]

sp.speaker: La. Bert.
sp.p: Hang thee, thou'rt good for nothing,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: But • leering and fooling.

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: And how do you, forsooth? I profess.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: And truly, I know what I know, and there's an end,

sp.speaker: Lady Bertlam.
sp.p: Of an old Song, Few words are best.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Ne're go, I'm the greatest man in the Nation▪ I profess I, ne're stir now: Think you what you will, forsooth Mother, as I'm here.

sp.speaker: Woodfleet.
sp.p: I profess, ne're stir, as I'm here, there's no enduring it, law now▪ as I'm here; and therefore farewel, as I'm here, for Ile be gone, ne're stir now.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Now Champion, what think you of your General Philagathus?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: A ro • e on't, I know not what to think on't: Was ever such a Ra • e committed upon a poor She City before? Lay her legs open to the wide world, for every Rogue to peep in her Breech. I

sp.speaker: 3 Prentice.
sp.p: 'Tis Monstrous!

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Is this the Cities Champion?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Well, On my Conscience he's honest for all this: The plaguy Rump has done this Mischief: Well, Club stand stiff to thy Master, some body shall suffer for't: I say no more.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: We shall be Coop'd up shortly for Hawks-meat in our Cellars, while they possess our Shops, and Feast upon our Mistresses▪

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Well, Ile Warrant the Souldiery will be honest for all this, and then we'l Sindge the Maggots out of the louzy Rump, or else Swindge me.

sp.speaker: 4 Prentice.
sp.p: News Boys, News.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: From whence, from Tripulo?

sp.speaker: 4 Prentice.
sp.p: From Guildhall, you Knaves: We shall have a Free Parliament.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Hy, hy, hy.

sp.speaker: 4 Prentice.
sp.p: The General and the City are agreed, and he has promis'd it.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Oh noble Philagathus!

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: Brave Phylagathus!

sp.speaker: 3 Prentice.
sp.p: Honorable Philagathus!

sp.speaker: 4 Prentice.
sp.p: Renowned Philagathus!

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Now you Infidels, What think you now? Has your Fears and Jealousies left you, or will you still damn your selves up with dirty Suspition. You that spoke even now you should be Coop'd up for Hawks-meat, shall be Cramm'd up for • apons; your Cellars shall become Ware-houses, your Shops Exchanges, and your Mistresses persons of honor.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: And, what shall we be?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Squires of the Body: Honor sufficient enough for men of our rank, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Oh brave Champion!

sp.speaker: 1. Prentice.
sp.p: I tell you, I will have no more of that: Where is Lilly now?

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: In one of the Twelve houses.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: We'l fire him out of 'em.

sp.speaker: 3 Prentice.
sp.p: How will the Man in the Moon drink Clarret then?

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Clarret is best burnt, Sir, by your leave.

sp.speaker: 3 Prentice.
sp.p: I, but Lilly has Eighteen houses.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: A Bakers dozen: we'l fire the odd end first.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A Match, a Match; we'l do't.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: But now I think on't, we must have no fireing of houses, there's a Statute against it: Better once Wise than never.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Oh brave Sack!

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: We'l be merry to night, I'm resolv'd on't, or else never let Prentices presume to be honest agen, and therefore follow me: God bless the General!

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Now Secretary, where's your Titles now? Not so much as a title of 'em remaining, all sunk in the Sand-box.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I'm between Silla and Carybdis, I must confess; and thou hast gravell'd me, my dear Priss.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Hang your Dog Poetry, it made my Lord thrive so ill as he did: I think thou didst infect him; he us'd to have a Serene brain, and Courage good enough: Sure the Viccar of Fools was his Ghostly Father: Be beat without a blow, there's a mystery indeed!

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Truly Priss, my Lord could not help it.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Not help it, there's a jest indeed, I'm sure he has helpt himself into prison for't, let who will help him out again. What course wilt thou take now, Secretary?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Not horse-coursing Priss, Ide have thee know that.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Why, thou'rt pretty well Timber'd for such an Imployment. Canst thou make pens?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Yes, and Ink too Priss, I tell you but so.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: There will be a Trade indeed for thee.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Nay, and the worst come to the worst, I can teach to Dance.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I confess thy Sword is alwayes Dancing.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: That's the Alamode is learnt in France.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Come, if thou canst Dance so well, let's have a frisk, if thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Truly Priss, I have not my Pumps in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: 'Tis well thy Mother left thee Wit enough for an Excuse.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: That is not all, look here, I can fence too—

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: What dost thou mean to do!—

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Set your right foot forward, keep a Close guard, have an Eye to your Enemies point, extend your Arm thus.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, the man is mad sure.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Traverse your ground sometimes reverse, as thus: Give back then, come on agen, play with his point: I • he makes a pass, put it by, make a home thrust thus, run him thorough, and he falls I Warrant you.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p:
Put up thy Fools-bawble there: I profess Ile
• all my Lady else.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Why, did it fright thee, Priss? seriously, I did but show thee what skill I had at my Weapon.

sp.speaker: Priscilla.
sp.p: Thou wouldst make a rare fellow to fence before the Bears, if there were any.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Why, Priss? I dare say I can kill any man living that can't defend himself.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I am of thy mind, that can't Defend himself.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Why Priss, such as fight must take all Advantages.

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: And I that do not • ight, will take the advantage to leave thee and thy foolery.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Nay, dear Priss, ne're go Ile follow thee.

div.stage: Enter Prentices with Faggots upon their Sholders, they pass the Stage whooping and hollowing.
Enter again whooping and hollowing with Rumps of Mutton upon Spits.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Roast the Rump, Roast the Rump.

div.stage: Enter a Boy upon a Colt-staffe carried by two, and others follow him whooping and hollowing.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Silence, Silence, I say.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Silence, Silence there.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.l: Gentlemen all, I tell you plain,
My Rump does itch, and we shall have rain.

div.stage: A piece of Wood is set forth painted like a pile of Faggots and Fire▪ and Faggots lying by to supply it.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, you are Welcome, Sit down, bring some Drink there, 'tis a night of Jubile, we'l want no Drink while the Rump roasts.
Here's a Health to your noble General.

sp.speaker: Souldiers.
sp.p: Thank you, young Man.

div.stage: Racks are set out one turn • th sp • t with Rumps on't.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p:
Baste the Rump
• oundly.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: It bastes it self, i • his been well • ed, a D • g take it: But pray give us some Drink too, we are almost Dry roasted.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p:
Begarr▪ dis b • very lite night▪ me can • ind my way to my loging▪ begarr very well if me not take a Cup to 〈◊〉
by the way: Now ga • soone, 〈◊〉 be de matter 〈◊〉 you?

sp.speaker: Prentices.
sp.p:
Some
〈…〉
the Bonfi • e
〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p:
Bonfi • es! begfrr me 〈…〉
be in the bonfires: here garsoone, 〈…〉
larshan to de bonsire?

sp.speaker: Musicians.
sp.p: We are Musicians, and will give you a Lesson Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: A Lesson, dat be very good, begarr me love itt vitt all mine heart, alle alle vic moy to de bonfire, begarr furboone Company de Souldate [they go to the bonfire.] dece Angletar, me love dem vitt all mine heart, play a lesson, or begar me vil brake a your Fiddells.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Oh brave Mounsieur!

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Furboone begarr now give me de merry Song, me give you de Larshan.

sp.speaker: Souldiers.
sp.p: Have you this Song? We came from Scotland.

sp.speaker: Musicians.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.l: Begarr me vill have a dat.
We came from Scotland with a small force,
With a hey down down a down a,
But with hearts far truer then steel;
We got by my fay,
The Glory oth' day,
Yet no man a hurt did feel:
sp.stage: [All sing the tune, and throw their hats about their heads.]
sp.l: When Bertlam first our Army did face,
Hey down down a down a,
He look'd as fierce as the Divel;
We feared a Rout,
But he Wheeled about,
The Gentleman was so Civil:
Our General Marcht with the Countreys love,
VVith a hey down down a down a,
All persons to him did address;
Small money we spent,
For we found as we VVent,
Good friends, and here find no less.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Furboone, begar furboone, done moy de toder Cup burn a de Rump.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: That has been often done in your Countrey, Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Begar me vilt dance about de Bonfire, come vit me men.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Oh brave Mounsieur!

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Let my Lady say what she will, I will see the Bonfire.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Begarr Metress you be a very fine Shentileveman, begarr me dance one time vitt you, nay begar you noe serve a me • oe.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I cannot dance indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Begarr me vill have on touch vitt you, Metress.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: What, before all this Company, Mounsieur?

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Datt me vill begarr.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Well, if I must dance, play Fortune my foe.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: No, Sellingers Round, We are beginning the World again.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Me vill have none of dat, me vill have a de Corrant of de foot sa saw, come Metress lend a [sings a tune.] me your hand, courage courage Metress.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Well, now indeed I must begon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Begar me vill see you to your loging, pardon a moy.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: By no means, I shall be knockt oth' head then.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Mee no care for dat, par ma moy adue Iee vou remercy pour dis • boone Company, adue petit garsoone.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Adue Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: 2 Prentice.
sp.p: What are you resolved to do? Every man to his home, or shall we make a Night on't.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A night on't, a night on't.

sp.speaker: 1 Prentice.
sp.p: Come to the next Bonfire.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: To the next Bonfire, to the next Bonfire.

div.stage: Enter Lockwhit, Stoneware, Huson, and Desborough.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: We have played our Cards fair.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: I deny it, We have not played our Cards fair.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: B • ed Sirs, then yee have plaid then faw, and thats faw play geod feath, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: A Fool had the shuffling of them, the game had gone better else.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: The faw deel himself was Trump, Sirs; I think s • rrs wee ha had nee geod luck, Sir • , this bout.

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p: We are lost Sirs, utterly lost.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: No Sir, we are found Sir, catcht in a Net of our own making.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Thou wouldst give all the Shooes in thy Shop to be ont of't.

sp.speaker: Huson▪
sp.p: Is there no remedy my Lord Lockwhit?

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p:
No remedy 〈…〉
• ill.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred, 〈◊〉 no 〈…〉 , hees my Noble Lyer Sirs.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Who • e Kee ••• of the 〈…〉 now?

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Where will you find your 1000. l. p. annum now.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p:
Bred Sir •
▪
〈◊〉 y • e gire▪ do yee gire? hees gatt rought Sirs, • eit •• er of any the gifts I had geen me geod feath.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: He •• k you Mr. Lawyer, have you e • re a Habulus Corpulus to remove us from the Storm is coming?

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: With a Sy •• ers, Razer, or what a Divel do you call it.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: You are politick, will you sell a penny worth of Pollicy, Sir?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred, he had meere need buy some to save his Cregg, Sirs.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Come lets let's leave the Law in the Lurch, and every man shift for himself? Adue! Mr. Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Adue! Mr. Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Adue! Mr. Lyer.

sp.speaker: Lockwhitt.
sp.p:
How monstrously have I expos'd my self to th' dirty Censure of the basest Creatures, things never mentioned but with scorn, and now I am become the Thesis unto theirs? The very Cobler reads a Lecture to me and I'm convinc'd, I should amend my manners, and
become Loyal Dictates long before Divinity discovered! There's no sin like that we know, and that we surfet in.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Do you want any Pens or Ink, Pens or Ink? Will you Fence, or will you Dance? What Pens and Ink do you want, Gentlemen?

div.stage: Enter Priscilla with her Basket of Oranges and Lemmons.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Fine civil Oranges, fine Lemmons▪ fine civil Oranges, fine Lemmons: Me thinks it sounds very well; a pox of her Tallnesse for me, no matter, ne're repine Wench, thy Trade's both pleasant and profitable, and if any Gentleman take me up, I am still, Fine civil Oranges, fine Lemmons.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Pens or Ink, Pens, Pens or Ink?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: 'Tis he.—Walker.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Priss, my Dear Priss.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Why, how now Secretary, thou seest my words are come to pass, I knew what a Lord thou wouldst be: But Fortunes a Whore.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: A whip take her: But shall we meet now: Priss?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: I think we are met Walker, although unhappily.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: I mean upon equal terms.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Will you buy a geodly Ballad, or a Scott Spur Sirs, will we buy a geodly ballad, or a Scott Spur Sirs, any thing to live in this World? Bred, if I should gang intoll my none Countrey, my Cregg would be stretcht two inches longer then 'tis: Will ye • buy a geodly ballad, or a Scott Spur Sirs, will a buy a Line a Iack-line, a Line a Iack Bertlams Line?

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: 'Tis the Lord Stoneware.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: No more Lord then thy self, Walker: Let's have some sport with him, Fine civil Oranges, fine Lemmons: Will your Lordship buy any Lemmons and Oranges? Fine civil Oranges, fine Lemmons.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Ink or Pens, Ink or Pens, will your Lordship buy any Ink or Pens for the Committee of no Safety?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred a geod what a Whore and a Knave is this.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Turnips, Turnips, Turnips hoe, did ever Lord cry Turnips before? But a pox of Lordship, would I had my old Farm over my head again, Turnips, Turnips Turnips hoe, Turn-up Mistress, and Turn-up the Maid, and who buyes my long Turnups ho!

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: He does it rarely well; Fine Oranges, fine civil Oranges, fine Lemmons.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Ink or Pens, Ink or Pens for the Lord Desborough.

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred 'tis he indeed, these are Witches sure, how does your geod Lady, Sirr?

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: What my Lord Stoneware?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Ne bred a geod Ime ne meere a Loord then yer neene self, my Honoor is in the dust, Sirr.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Have you any old Boots or Shoes to mend, I have helpt to under lay the Government this 20. years, and have been upon the mending hand, but I fear now I shall be brought to my Last, & therefore ought to mind my end; will you buy Shoes for Brooms, or Brooms for Shoes?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Or a Knave for a whip, or a whip for a Knave? Fine civil Oranges, Fine Lemmons.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Ink or Pens, Ink or Pens, how do you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Dost mock me fellow? Who are these?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: My geod friend.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Brother Huson, and how, and how?

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: And what, and what? and pox o' that, and that; lets imbrace however.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Cromwell with Boyes after her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: What Kitchin-stuffe have you Maids? was ever Princess brought to such a pass? what Kitchin-stuffe have you Maids?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Gammer Cromwell, our Maid calls you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Where you Rascall?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: In my—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: You Rogue do you abuse me? Ile claw your eyes out.
sp.stage: •• ings down her Tub and runs after him.

div.stage: Enter again presently and takes up her Tub.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: Oh Dick! Dick! Did ever I think to come to this? What Kitchin-stuffe have you Maids, Maids have you any Kitchin-stuffe Maids?

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Fine civil Oranges, fine Lemmons? Will your Ladyship buy any Oranges and Lemmons?

sp.speaker: Ms. Cr.
sp.p: Dost thou mock me Bag • ge? Ile be at thee presently.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: No indeed shee does not, 'tis Priss my Lady Bertlams Woman, and I am Walker her Secretary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: How? Thou hast walkt fair indeed, where is her Highnesse now?

sp.speaker: Priss.
sp.p: They say she intends to cry fresh Cheese & Cream.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: She has brought her hogs to a fair market.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: And so we have all me thinks.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: What art thou there too?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Bred an Ise here ta, and my geod Loord Desborough, bred a geod heeres eene a Iolly Company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: It somewhat palliates my miserie, That inafflictions yo • like Sharets be.

sp.speaker: Prissilla.
sp.p: Come let's mind our business, words are but wind▪ Fine civil Oranges, fine Lemmons.

sp.speaker: Walker.
sp.p: Ink or Pens, Ink or Pens, will you buy any Ink or Pens?

sp.speaker: Stoneware.
sp.p: Will yee buy a geodly Ballad, or a Scott Spurr, will yee buy a Iack-line a Iack Bertlams line, or a line for a Iack a Bertlam.

sp.speaker: Desbr.
sp.p: Turnips, Turnips, Turnips hoe! Turn-up Mistress, and Turn-up Maid, and Turn-up my Cousin and be not afraid of a long, long, Red Turn-up ho.

sp.speaker: Huson.
sp.p: Boots or Shooes, Boots or Shooes to mend?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cromwell.
sp.p: What Kitchin-stuffe have you Maids? what Kitchin-stuffe have you Maids?

sp.speaker: Lockwhit.
sp.p:
I am a poor Lawyer Gentlemen, and can shew you Legerdemain for your mony, no Hocus Po • us like me. I have two hands, neither of them disabled from taking • ees; have you any canses to split? for that's my
Doom, my Bag is a Receptacle for them; I am for that
•• use brings me most profit, be it good or be it bad; but indeed have been better experienced in the bad, and now would • ain follow the good Cause and turn honest; but a man shall hardly grow rich then you'l say, and then 'twill vex a man.
sp.l: How e're Ile try' • , for to my greif I find
Riches ill got, do scatter with the Wind.
sp.p:
Have you any work for a poor Housell Lawyer, for all
〈◊〉 honest Lawyer, I am your next man, Gentleman.
sp.l: Ambition and 〈◊〉 Avarice, adue!
How e're your Gl •• yes yes seem, they are not true.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: Th' Authors name's committed to your trust▪
You have here in a MIRROUR seen the Crimes
Of the late P • ageantry Changeling Times.
Let me Survey your Brows—They are Serene,
Not clouded, or disturb'd with what y'ave seen:
None whose grand Guilt appears toucht to the quick▪
And in Revenge wou'd gainst their MIRROUR kick.
Nor in a Corner can I one descry
Sneaking, that dare give Bellarmine the Lie.
So that we do conclude, the Authors fear
Is now remov'd; there's no Phanatick here.
You are a glorious Presence, cleer as Day,
And innocent as Buds that sprout in May.
Tis you must gild our Hemisphere, and give
A life to us who willingly would live.
Then, If you please to grant • us our Request,
Signe us your Servants, and we • l do, our best.
